bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Alberto Recio, December 23, 1941

div1.p: Hench inquires whether the true site of Camp Lazear was ever surveyed. He wonders whether Ramos is still Minister of Defense and is still interested in the memorialization of Camp Lazear, since Hench heard that the entire Cuban cabinet resigned.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Alberto Recio, December 23, 1941
div1.opener:
Y F.
December 23, 1941
Dr. Alberto Recio
Ave. de la Independencia y Montero
Habana, Cuba
My dear Doctor Recio:
div1.p:
Thank you very kindly for your nice letter acknowledging the
receipt of my article on the “Conquerors of Yellow Fever.”

You did not answer a couple of questions which I thought that
I had asked you. Have you been able to arrange for an accurate survey
of the true site of Camp Lazear? Last year you said you hoped to arrange
this.

Is Dr. Ramos still the Minister of National Defense and is he
still interested in the memorialization of Camp Lazear? I heard some
months ago that almost the whole Cuban cabinet had resigned. I realize
that in these times of war we cannot do much toward memorializing the
camp at the present but I want to keep things going slowly so that we
can complete this project in due time. I certainly appreciate your con-
tinued interest in it. You have been exceedingly helpful.

You doubtless already knew that among the earliest patients which
Dr. Finlay inoculated are two who are living at the San Jose Farm in the
Collegio Belin, this same farm which later became Camp Lazear. That makes
the San Jose Farm doubly interesting, not only to the Americans but to the
Cubans.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
